title: Recognition:Theo,Ethics,Poltcs
ci_attrs:
• DI: Area II
  • DI: Area V
description: The cultural weight of the category of “recognition” has swelled dramatically in recent decades. It has figured in significant social movements like Black Lives Matter and in popular business trends like “personal branding.” It seems that recognition is widely held to be an important component of human flourishing. The prospect of its attainment can justify struggle and strategic pursuit. The reality of its deprivation can spark protest and denunciation. Parallel to this trend in popular discourse, theoretical treatments of recognition in philosophy, social theory, and theology have proliferated. Whether or not there is a genealogical relationship between these two trends, the study of theories of recognition is significant not only in its own right as an intellectual endeavor but also in its ability to help us respond appropriately to problems surrounding recognition in various contemporary culture milieus. This class examines two of the seminal theoretical treatments of recognition from the nineteenth century, surveys significant twentieth- and twenty-first-century theories of recognition, and considers what a Christian ethic of right recognition might entail. Area II.
